course.subject: SOSC
course.name: Understanding China, 1700-2000: A Data Analytic Approach
course.description: The purpose of this course is to summarize some of the new directions in Chinese history and Chinese social science during the last two decades. The course eschews the standard chronological narrative arc for an analytic approach that focuses on specific data sets and distinguishes between data measurement and the production of new facts, and how these new facts complicate our understanding of current social theories. The primary motivation for this course design is to stimulate critical thinking, and to encourage students to question received wisdom.

reviews.comment_grading:
40% Group oral presentations
15% Group oral comments
25% Individual Reflective essay
10% Individual Class Participation and Discussion
10% Group teamwork ( Peer evaluation)

I fkd up and handed in late my reflective essay and didn't participate much in class discussion. Group presentations and comments are not the best. I got B. I think grading isn't bad considering I'm not doing well in this course.

It seems that the professor doesn't fail students. However I feel that it isn't fair that those who free-ride their group for the whole semester could pass the course.

Also, the score came out on Sep 1, 2021. -_-
reviews.comment_workload:
Heavy workload due to presentations.

1 1000 words individual reflective essay.
(1 group presentation + 1 group comment) per week, 8 ppts in total.

Presentation : 15 min, 15 pages of ppt.
Comment : 5 min, 1 page of ppt.
5-6 people per group. Unless there is free-rider in your group.
Classes on Tuesday and Thursday.

1 subject per class. Each subject is divided into 3 different questions for groups to do presentations.
3 random groups doing presentations, 3 other groups doing comments in each class. For those doing presentations on Tuesday, they need to upload their draft ppt before Monday afternoon, having around 4 days for preparations. For those doing presentations on Thursday, they need to upload their draft ppt before Wednesday afternoon, having around 1 day for preparations.
Plenty recorded videos and extra readings. There are 5 extra readings per subject on average. Each extra reading is about 30 pages long. They are essential for the presentations.

reviews.author: Lokman
reviews.title: Professor and TA are professional!
reviews.comment_content:
Three big topics:
1. ‘the Fittest’ as seen through socio-demographic studies of comparative population behavior - mortality, marriage, and reproduction – and their interaction with economic conditions and community and family organization.
2. ‘the Chosen’ as seen through the lens of comparative opportunity for education and to some extent work. We do so because education is increasingly a necessary precondition everywhere for employment.
3. ‘the Wealthy’ measured by landed and residential property since such tangible assets are much harder to hide and therefore better recorded than other types of wealth.
reviews.comment_teaching:
James Z. Lee and his team are very professional and willing to help and always being tolerant of different ideas.
He has a wide range of knowledge, history, sociology... so he is always able to give comments and bring new knowledge based on students' ideas.
We have a three hour class per week, but the class is mainly directed by students, we present and give comments to the present groups, and have discussions on the present groups' topics.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grading! I didn't expect to get an A+ on this course, since I don't think our groups' presentations have very high quality based on the contents, and I am not that active in class, only say some of my thoughts and ideas when they came up to my mind, but not every class.
So I think the reflection essay is very important because I did put some effort into that essay.
reviews.comment_workload:
In the Spring term, each group has 5 presentations, each group give a presentation every two weeks and those groups that don't need to present that week need to make comments on the present groups.
It seems a lot of workload at first, but when you get used to it, it is acceptable and not that difficult.
And one reflection essay (1000) at the end of the class.

reviews.author: Dicaprio
reviews.title: VERY intense summer course that I dropped.
reviews.comment_content:
Chinese history course. focus on year 1700~2000. Heavy workload so not recommended for common core. it is a 3000 level course so it is very challenging. Only for people who like Chinese history and love doing presentations.

L1 18 July Introduction: Understanding China / Understanding Inequality
L2 20 July The Fittest: Who Survives. G1,G9 presentation, G11, G4 comment
L3 22 July The Fittest: Who Reproduces. G2, G8 presentation, G10, G5 comment
L4 25 July The Fittest: Who Marries. G3, G7 presentation, G9, G6 comment
L5 27 July The Chosen: Who Gets Education in the Qing. G4, G11 presentation, G8, G1 comment
L6 29 July The Chosen: Who Gets Education in Republican China. G5, G10 presentation, G7, G2 comment
L7 1 August The Chosen: Who Gets Education in the People’s Republic of China. G6, G9 presentation, G11, G3 comment
L8 3 August The Chosen: Comparing the Best and the Rest. G8, G1 presentation, G10, G4 comment
L9 5 August The Wealthy: Who Gets Property in the Past. G7, G2 presentation, G9, G5 comment
L10 8 August The Wealthy: Who Gets Property During Rural Reconstruction. G11, G3 presentation, G8, G6 comment
L11 10 August The Wealthy: Who Gets Property Today. G10, G4 presentation. G7, G1 comment
L12 12 August The Powerful: Who Gets Political Authority in Qing and Republican China. G6, G5 presentation, G3, G2 comment
reviews.comment_teaching:
the professor have a total of 55~60 10 minutes long lecture videos that you watch before every class. and he is basically reading from the powerpoints directly in those pre-recorded videos.

the professor don't teach directly. he teach by asking students to present and give comments afterwards.
reviews.comment_grading:
1. Group Oral Presentations x2 (35%)
-15 slide powerpoint (preparation time: 30 hours~1 week) (first lecture on Monday. the 2 unlucky groups need to submit their presentation powerpoints on Tuesday 17:00 and present it on Wednesday second lecture)

2. Group Oral Comments x2 (15%)
-Comment on assigned group's presentation.

3. Individual 1000 word reflective essay (25%)
-900~1100 words on some aspects you learnt in this course

4. Individual Class Participation and Discussion (15%)
-After the comment group finish their comment,
other students need to actively comment and ask questions to earn these points.

5. Group Teamwork (10%)
-students peer assessment
reviews.comment_workload:
it is a 4 week course and you need to do 2 group presentation powerpoint, 2
group comment powerpoint, 1 individual 1000 word essay in total

Before every lecture, you need to watch 3~8 10 minutes lecture videos on HKMOOC, read around 40 pages of books/reading materials, and read the 2 presentation powerpoints prepared by your classmates. You are expected to actively comment and ask questions after other people's presentation for participation points.

There are a constant 11 groups. The class size is 36. The class was full with a waitlist of 30 students before the class starts. However, only around 20 students enrolled with no waitlist after the add/drop period. The group is assigned to you in random so you cant choose groupmayes. The group size was 3~4 but became 1~2 after everyone dropped (including me). so the workload is very high.
